anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.178 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated November 27, 1961 of the Central Government Labour Court, Delhi Camp at Madras

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated November 27, 1961 of the Central Government Labour Court, Delhi Camp at Madras in L.C.A. No. 564 of 1961.

facts.text: in L.C.A. No. 564 of 1961

anchor.surface_text: in L.C.A. No. 564 of 1961. C. Setalvad, J.N. Hazarika and K.P. Gupta for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 2, 1963 by DAS GUPTA J.

anchor.surface_text: December 2, 1.963. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA J.-This appeal arises out

facts.text: R. Chacko was working as a clerk in the Coimbatore Branch of the appellant-Bank

anchor.surface_text: The respondent R. Chacko was working as a clerk in the Coimbatore Branch of the appellant-Bank when by an order dated June 19, 1959,

facts.text: By order dated June 19, 1959, R. Chacko was promoted as Accountant and transferred to the Alleppy Branch

anchor.surface_text: he was promoted as Accountant and was transferred to the Alleppy Branch of the Bank. The appellants pay in the new post was fixed by an order on July 16, 1960.

facts.text: Pay fixed by order on July 16, 1960: Rs. 120 basic pay from January 1, 1960

anchor.surface_text: The appellants pay in the new post was fixed by an order on July 16, 1960. By this order he was allowed Rs. 120 as basic pay in the new grade of Rs. 120-10-160 from January 1, 1960.

facts.text: Rs. 10 per month as CAIIB allowance from August 1, 1960

anchor.surface_text: From August 1, 1960 and thereafter he was allowed to draw Rs. 10 per month as CAIIB allowance.

facts.text: Application under s. 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act by respondent

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners case in the application under S. 33C 2  is based on the companytention that after his promotion

facts.text: Claim to special allowance of Rs. 40 under Para 164 of the Sastry Award from date of joining as accountant July 13, 1959

anchor.surface_text: that after his promotion to the post of accountant with additional supervisory duties he was entitled to the special allowance of Rs. 40 tinder Para 164 of the Sastry Award. His case is that he was entitled from the date of his joining as accountant, i.e., from July 13, 1959

facts.text: Claimed basic pay Rs.95 old grade with increments, Rs.40 special allowance, dearness allowance; total Rs.4,495.22 entitled

anchor.surface_text: a  to a basic pay of Rs. 95 of his old grade with annual increments due on December 1, every year i.e., at the rate of Rs. 95 in the month of August, September, October and November 1959 and thereafter at the rate of Rs. 100 from December 1959 to November 1960, and thereafter at the rate of Rs. 106 from December 1960  b  special allowance of Rs. 40 per month

facts.text: Actually paid Rs.3637.73 for period July 13, 1959 to end of March 1961

anchor.surface_text: The total amount to which he would be entitled thus would be Rs. 4,495.22. The amount actually paid to him for the period July 13, 1959 to the end of March 1961

facts.text: Claimed additional Rs.855.49

anchor.surface_text: He claimed to be entitled to the additional amount of Rs. 855.49 and prayed that the Labour Court be pleased to issue a certificate

facts.text: Bank contended application under s.33C(2) incompetent

anchor.surface_text: In resisting this application the Bank companytended  1  that such an application under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 was incompetent,

facts.text: Bank contended jurisdiction with Industrial Tribunal not Labour Court

anchor.surface_text: 2  that in any case the matter would be one within the jurisdiction of an industrial tribunal and number the Labour Court,

facts.text: Bank contended Sastry Award ceased operative from March 31, 1959

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the Sastry Award had ceased to be operative from March 31, 1959 long before the date of the respondents appointment as an accountant

facts.text: Bank contended respondent ceased to be workman on appointment as accountant

anchor.surface_text: and so numberbenefits accrued to him under that award and  4  by his appointment as accountant the respondent had ceased to be a workman

facts.text: Labour Court rejected all objections and allowed application, computed Rs.855.49 due

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court rejected all these objections and allowing the application, companyputed the amount due to the respondent from the Bank to be Rs. 855.49.

facts.text: Sastry Award remained in force until March 31, 1959 per s.4 Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decision Act, 1955

anchor.surface_text: In support of the third objection raised by the Bank Mr. Setalvad drew our attention to s. 4 of the Industrial Disputes  Banking Companies  Decision Act, 1955, and argued that in view of this provision the respondent was number entitled to any benefit of the Sastry Award in July 1959

facts.text: Labour Court found respondent was workman, merely senior clerk with supervisory duties

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court appears to have taken proper numbere of this distinction between accountants who are really officers and accountants who are merely senior clerks with supervisory duties and on a companysideration of the evidence on the record as regards the duties actually performed by the respondent Chacko, has companye to the companyclusion that he was merely a senior clerk,

facts.text: Resolution by Board of Directors dated July 18, 1959 authorizing Accountant powers

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Setalvad drew our attention to a companyy of the resolution passed by the Board of Directors under which the respondent as Accountant was authorised to make, draw, sign, endorse, purchase, sell, discount and negotiate Bills of Exchange, Hundies, Drafts, Cheques, Promissory Notes and other Nego- tiable instruments

facts.text: Circular-letter dated July 18, 1959 including respondent's signature

anchor.surface_text: This resolution was dated July 18, 1959 and on the same date a circular-letter was issued to all branches sending a binder companytaining specimen signatures of all the officers of the Bank and the respondents name was also included in this list.

facts.text: Document Ex.1 dated August 28, 1961 listing duties of respondent as mostly clerical

anchor.surface_text: A truer picture of his actual functions appears from a document dated August 28, 1961 signed by the Agent which was put in evidence as Ex.1. and the companyrectness of which does number appear to have been challenged on behalf of the Bank authorities.

facts.text: No power of attorney granted to respondent

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court has also pointed out that numberpower of attorney was granted to Mr. Chacko.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds no reason to interfere with Labour Court's conclusion that respondent is workman

anchor.surface_text: We can find numbermistake in the approach of the Labour Court to the question number can we see any justification for interfering with its companyclusion on the evidence in the case.

This appeal arises out of an application under s. 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act. The respondent R. Chacko was working as a clerk

arguments.claim: Distinction between award in operation (s.19(3)) and binding on parties (s.19(6))

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 19 3  the award remains in operation for a period of one year.  The words from the date on which the award becomes enforceable under s. 17A were inserted after the words period of one year by the amending Act of 1956 . Section 19 6  is in these words- Notwithstanding the expiry of the period of operation under sub-section  3 , the award shall continue to be binding

arguments.claim: Even after expiry of operation and binding periods, award continues as contract between parties

anchor.surface_text: it will continue to have its effect as a contract between the parties that has been made by industrial adjudication in place of the old contract. So long as the award remains in operation under s. 19 3 , s. 23 c  stands in the way of any strike by the workmen and lock-out by the employer in respect of any matter covered by the award.

arguments.claim: Accountants prima facie workmen unless directional/controlling duties (per Sastry para 332,167)

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the mere fact that he was designated as accountant would number take him out of the category of workman. This was recognised in para 332 of the Sastry Award when it was said- The categories of workmen known as Head Clerks, Accountants, Head Cashiers should prima facie be taken as workmen

arguments.claim: Respondent's duties mainly clerical with supervision, not managerial; entitled as workman

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court appears to have taken proper notice of this distinction between accountants who are really officers and accountants who are merely senior clerks with supervisory duties and on a consideration of the evidence on the record as regards the duties actually performed by the respondent Chacko, has come to the conclusion that he was merely a senior clerk,

arguments.claim: Promotion to officer grade reducing pay unreasonable; not intended to undo Sastry allowance

anchor.surface_text: It is pertinent to notice that on the Banks case a workman in the position of Chacko would on promotion to the rank of an officer from that of a workman be financially a loser by being deprived of the special allowance which he would have got as a workman with supervisory duties without obtaining sufficient recompense for the same

holdings.text: The first objection that application under s. 33C(2) is incompetent is concluded by precedent in Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan holding such applications lie under s. 33C(2).

anchor.surface_text: The first objection raised by the Bank is number companycluded by the decision of this Court in the Central Bank of India v. S. Rajagopalan  1  where it has been held that such an application by workmen lies under s. 33C 2  of the Act. In support of the second objection Mr. Setalvad drew our attention to the second schedule to the Industrial Disputes Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bound by Supreme Court precedent directly on point.

holdings.text: Labour Court has jurisdiction under s.33C(2), not Industrial Tribunal, as per s.7 and Second Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly, therefore, the Labour Court as specified by the government and number the Industrial Tribunal has jurisdiction to deal with this matter. In support of the third objection raised by the Bank Mr. Setalvad drew our attention to s. 4 of the Industrial Disputes  Banking Companies  Decision Act, 1955,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second Schedule refers to s.7 which allows assignment of functions under Act including s.33C(2) to Labour Court.

holdings.text: Sastry Award did not cease to provide benefits after March 31, 1959; s.4 IDBCDA affects operation under s.19(3) but not binding under s.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: The provision in s. 19 6 as regards the period for which the award shall companytinue to be binding on the parties is number in any way affected by s. 4 of the Industrial Dispute  Banking Companies  Decision Act, 1955. Quite apart from this, however, it appears to us that even if an award has ceased to be in operation or in force and has ceased to be binding on the parties under the provisions of s. 19 6  it will companytinue to have its effect as a companytract between the parties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes 'operation' (s.19(3)) from 'binding' (s.19(6)); s.4 non-obstante affects only operation.

holdings.text: Even after expiry of operation and binding periods, award continues to govern as contract between parties until displaced.

anchor.surface_text: it will companytinue to have its effect as a companytract between the parties that has been made by industrial adjudication in place of the old companytract. So long as the award remains in operation under s. 19 3 , s. 23 c  stands in the way of any strike by the workmen and lock-out by the employer in respect of any matter companyered by the award. Again, so long as the award is binding on a party,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose of industrial adjudication implies persistence as new contract post ss.19(3)/(6), unaffected by ss.23/29 expiry.

holdings.text: Respondent remained workman on appointment as accountant; merely senior clerk with supervisory duties.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court appears to have taken proper numbere of this distinction between accountants who are really officers and accountants who are merely senior clerks with supervisory duties and on a companysideration of the evidence on the record as regards the duties actually performed by the respondent Chacko, has companye to the companyclusion that he was merely a senior clerk,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence (Ex.1 duties clerical, no PoA, limited exercise of powers) and Sastry Award paras 167/332 support; no error in Labour Court finding.

holdings.text: All objections rejected; Labour Court order upheld, respondent entitled to Rs.855.49.

anchor.surface_text: We can find numbermistake in the approach of the Labour Court to the question number can we see any justification for interfering with its companyclusion on the evidence in the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No grounds to interfere with Labour Court's factual and legal conclusions on all issues.
